articles.headline: Losing Bid for Postal Contract Proves Costly for Electric-Vehicle Maker
articles.snippet: Workhorse, a small truck maker with big ambitions, was counting on the deal for a surge in revenue. Its shares lost $2 billion in value.
articles.abstract: Workhorse, a small truck maker with big ambitions, was counting on the deal for a surge in revenue. Its shares lost $2 billion in value.
articles.lead_paragraph: It wasn’t the first love affair to end with bad news from the letter carrier.
articles.byline: By Neal E. Boudette and Hiroko Tabuchi

articles.headline: Hong Kong’s Lesson to Schoolchildren: Love China, No Questions Asked
articles.snippet: Through new lesson plans and expensive publishing projects, the government hopes to teach future generations a curated lesson about the city’s past.
articles.abstract: Through new lesson plans and expensive publishing projects, the government hopes to teach future generations a curated lesson about the city’s past.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — The orders seemed innocuous, even obvious: Primary school students in Hong Kong should read picture books about Chinese traditions and learn about famous sites such as the Forbidden City in Beijing or the Great Wall.

articles.headline: Inside a Battle Over Race, Class and Power at Smith College
articles.snippet: A student said she was racially profiled while eating in a college dorm. An investigation found no evidence of bias. But the incident will not fade away.
articles.abstract: A student said she was racially profiled while eating in a college dorm. An investigation found no evidence of bias. But the incident will not fade away.
articles.lead_paragraph: NORTHAMPTON, Mass. — In midsummer of 2018, Oumou Kanoute, a Black student at Smith College, recounted a distressing American tale: She was eating lunch in a dorm lounge when a janitor and a campus police officer walked over and asked her what she was doing there.

articles.headline: Powell Says Better Child Care Policies Might Lift Women in Work Force
articles.snippet: The Fed chair said better caregiving options was an “area worth looking at” for Congress, while reiterating the central bank’s full-employment pledge.
articles.abstract: The Fed chair said better caregiving options was an “area worth looking at” for Congress, while reiterating the central bank’s full-employment pledge.
articles.lead_paragraph: Jerome H. Powell, the Federal Reserve chair, suggested on Wednesday that improved child care support policies from the government might help pull more women into the labor market.

articles.headline: A Recall for Newsom in California? Talk Grows as Governors Come Under Attack
articles.snippet: Fellow Democrats have defended Gov. Gavin Newsom, lavishly praising his handling of the pandemic. But conservatives say his shutdowns have been destructive.
articles.abstract: Fellow Democrats have defended Gov. Gavin Newsom, lavishly praising his handling of the pandemic. But conservatives say his shutdowns have been destructive.
articles.lead_paragraph: SACRAMENTO — Long before Orrin Heatlie filed papers to recall Gavin Newsom, he knew the odds were against unseating the suave ex-mayor of San Francisco who ascended to become California’s governor.

articles.headline: Can Clubhouse Move Fast Without Breaking Things?
articles.snippet: The 11-month-old audio social network is compelling. It also has some very grown-up problems.
articles.abstract: The 11-month-old audio social network is compelling. It also has some very grown-up problems.
articles.lead_paragraph: A few nights ago, after my weekly trip to the grocery store, I sat in my car glued to Clubhouse, the invitation-only social audio app.

articles.headline: ‘V.I.P. Immunization’ for the Powerful and Their Cronies Rattles South America
articles.snippet: A wave of corruption scandals is exposing how the powerful and well-connected in South America jumped the line to get vaccines early. Public dismay is turning into anger.
articles.abstract: A wave of corruption scandals is exposing how the powerful and well-connected in South America jumped the line to get vaccines early. Public dismay is turning into anger.
articles.lead_paragraph: LIMA, Peru — The hope brought by the arrival of the first vaccines in South America is hardening into anger as inoculation campaigns have spiraled into scandal, cronyism and corruption, rocking national governments and sapping trust in the political establishment.
articles.byline: By Mitra Taj, Anatoly Kurmanaev, Manuela Andreoni and Daniel Politi
